advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I did click" <br><br> Cool french young boy, proud of its brand new Adam. Only the expansion module #3 version was available in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEROX RANGE, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #5 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">If you could talk to Thomas Edison, he'd tell you what it was like to turn the light on in 1879. You could tell him about some bright idea of the 20th century... particularly, a technological phenomenon that can handle everything from solar heat control to lighting you home via voice command. The Apple personal computer...<br> ... With Apple, Edison could've written a program to determine why some filaments burned longer than others...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Never before in the history of modern computers has there been available a totally portable machine with the ability to cope with so many demands, to so many people, in so many different business areas.<br> Epson, with over 20 years experience in designing and manufacturing high quality printers, have produced the HX-20, a precision machine with its own rechargeable power supply that can be used for just about any task within to days discerning business: from data capture to word processing, from card indexing to sales order entry.<br> Communicating with other machines is no problem and the HX-20 is easily coupled to one of our fine printers. You can even link in another main computer system by using an acoustic coupler.<br> Don't be fooled by its size, the HX-20 has all the software back-up you'd expect from a much larger machine and incorporates many "bigger computer" features - 16k RAM expandable to 32k with serial interfaces, a full size typewriter keyboard, it's own built in LCD screen and a dot matrix microprinter. A micro­cassette facility is available as an optional extra.<br> A complete computer that will either stand on its own or could be the obvious extension to your existing system.<br> More and more people are finding out just how big the small compact HX-20 is. Why don't you find out for yourself - you­ owe it to your business.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A computer for all french people"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #6 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The facts speak for themselves. The QUAY 500 SERIES offers more for the money than North Star Horizon computers...<br><br> ...The bottom line is simple. There is a new star in the computer field. The 500 SERIES by Quay. It outshines all of the competition.<br><br></font> A little pretentious tone!</blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer, also known as the Talking Computer, was fully compatible with the Apple II and the CP/M operating systems thanks to its dual processor motherboard (6502 and Z80). It was manufactured by the Creative Technology Cie. which will later become wide-world known for its Sound Blaster cards. Cubic 99 also had a vocal synthesizer which allowed the user to record and to reproduce words in English or Chinese language. Several commands of the BASIC language also allowed the computer to say sentences entered as string variables. The sound was of poor quality, but it was the best in low-cost sound technology of the time. Creative was a company based in Singapore. The graphic on the screen of the model shown is celebrating Singapore's 25th year of independence, which was in 1990.
Thanks to Philip Hurst for his help.
computer.graphics: 40 x 40 or 280 x 192 pixels (2 to 18 Hi-Res. pages)
computer.keyboard: Full-Stroke 68 keys with numeric keypad & function keys
computer.media: 2 x F.D. 5.25 inches - 40 tracks - 48 TPI - 160 KB
computer.name: CUBIC 99
computer.peripherals: Cubic 10 MB Winchester Hard-disk unit and Apple ll cards
computer.ports: RGB and Composite video, Microphone jack, serial and parallel interfaces, Light-pen

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Composite B/W video chinch plug<br> <b>(3)</b> RGB video output connector<br> <b>(4)</b> Microphone jack for voice recording<br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Light-pen connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Serial interface connector (mounted on serial card)<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE CUBIC 99</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 64 KB RAM memory chips (8 x 4164)<br> <b>(2)</b> Serial interface card<br> <b>(3)</b> Chinese characters generator card<br> <b>(4)</b> 128 KB RAM optional card<br> <b>(5)</b> Floppy drives controller card<br> <b>(6)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(7)</b> fan<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CUBIC MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Z80-A microprocessor<br> <b>(2)</b> 6502 microprocessor<br> <b>(3)</b> 64 KB RAM memory chips (8 x 4164)<br> <b>(4)</b> Two ROM chips holding the Talking Basic interpreter<br> <b>(5)</b> RAM expansion card specific slot<br> <b>(6)</b> Apple ll compatible slots<br> <b>(7)</b> Analog joysticks connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b>(9)</b> RGB video out connector<br> <b>(10)</b> Composite B/W video out connector<br> <b>(11)</b> Speech synthetiser ROM chip<br> <b>(12)</b> Keyboard connector<br></blockquote>
